Key Match Events: The Golden State Warriors won 118-112 against the Boston Celtics at TD Garden.
The Warriors became the first team to win in Boston in the regular season since the New York Knicks on April 11.
Stephen Curry scored a season-high 27 points and dished out nine assists against the Celtics.
Buddy Hield's three-pointer with 47 seconds left gave Golden State a 111-104 advantage and sealed the win.
Post-Match Reflections: Stephen Curry stated that the Warriors 'haven't done anything yet' despite their 7-1 start and being tied for the best record in the Western Conference.
Curry emphasized the importance of winning games they are supposed to win, stealing a couple on the road against good teams, and protecting their home court.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Warriors shot 14-of-34 from three-point range and held the Celtics to 40 points in the first half.
Both offenses scored a combined 139 points in the second half.
The Celtics battled back after trailing by as many as 14 points in the third quarter, with Derrick White's three-pointer giving Boston an 85-84 lead in the fourth quarter.
The Warriors went on a 19-4 run over four minutes to regain the lead.
Others: There was curiosity around the Warriors coming into the season after losing Klay Thompson.
The Warriors focused on building depth around Curry and Draymond Green, bringing in Buddy Hield, Kyle Anderson, and De'Anthony Melton.
Head coach Steve Kerr is using a strategy of rotating players, with 13 players averaging at least 12 minutes of playing time and no one playing more than 28.1 minutes per game.
The Warriors rank second in defensive rating, third in offensive rating, and first in net rating.
